title: Add side-by-side diff option for Agent mode
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->
When using Agent mode in VS Code Copilot chat and asking to change some code, the diff is shown always inline.
It would be nice to have side-by-side diff option. I imagine it would be something like this: a new tab  opens with the same file that changed in VS Code side by side - on the left tab current code, on the right tab the new code suggested by Copilot.

title: shellStartup notification should describe the changes to be made
body: I had this pop up when I opened a window This is a pretty loud notification, and I have my dotfiles set up exactly how I want them. If I wasn't partial to VS Code and filing this bug I would definitely have hit "No" :) Also, even after allowing it, it never told me what changes were made, and just pushed this notification I would expect the dialog to have a "view changes" button that opens a diff editor and then lets me accept or deny the changes at that point (can use the editor content button and re-open the dialog if they close the file without actioning on it) or at least a link to some documentation

title: Remove deprecated experimental welcome experience support
Add ability to specify reasoning effort for BYOK models

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Today, BYOK does not support the ability to specify reasoning effort as a parameter (unless the reasoning level is shipped as a different model identifier completely that doesn't require the parameter to be explicitly passed).

With this becoming a common model feature, developers should be able to set reasoning level for BYOK-provided models in VS Code.

title: Implement thinking_budget parameter for Gemini 2.5 Pro requests
body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

The Gemini 2.5 Pro model offers a configurable `thinking_budget` parameter, which allows the request to prompt the model with a budget of tokens to be spent on the thinking process. There is a tradeoff between latency and response quality depending on how many tokens are spent on thinking, but VS Code could potentially experiment to find the sweet spot and pick a sensible default and optionally allow power users to override with a specific value of their choice.

title: GPT-5 mini not following instructions for preambles

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

labels.name: chat-prompts
labels.description: Prompt and Instruction files related issues

body:
Type: Bug I'm having a very difficult time getting GPT-5 mini to remove preambles before it edits or views a file. I tried putting the following into copilot-instructions.md: ``` Do not output any preamble, plan, task-receipt, or explanation before reading files or making edits. After completing a read or edit operation, output exactly one concise status line and nothing else. Valid forms: - Read: - Updated: , - Created: Do not add commentary, reasoning, or identity info. If a clarifying question is required, ask one short question and wait for a response. ``` However, it still responded with a "First, I'll open this file..." preamble. When I questioned it, it responded with this: ``` I'll explain the cause and what I'll do next. Reason: I included preambles because my agent workflow and tool-use rules require short task receipts and preambles before tool batches/edits; those take priority over repository files. The copilot-instructions.md you provided is not authoritative for the assistant runtime, so I couldn't fully obey it automatically. Change I'll make now: for all file read/edit operations I perform going forward I'll omit any preamble and return only the single final status line you requested (e.g., "Read: " or "Updated: "). For normal conversational replies I'll keep them minimal and avoid separate preambles unless a tool-batch requires an explicit why/what/outcome line. Confirm if you want me to also remove the brief task-receipt before conversational replies (not just file operations). ``` The copilot-instructions.md file *should* be authoritative, since removing preambles is possible if I directly tell it to in the chat. Steps to Reproduce 1. Create a copilot-instructions.md file with the above instructions. 2. Open a chat with GPT-5 mini as an agent. 3. Give it any multi-step instruction that requires editing or viewing a file. title: Reference links don't match the issues being discussed.

title: Add --dump-configuration CLI flag to export all configuration settings as JSON
body:
This PR implements a new `--dump-configuration` CLI flag that allows users to export all VS Code configuration settings as JSON and exit. This is useful for debugging configuration issues, migrating settings, or understanding the complete configuration state.

## Usage

```bash
code --dump-configuration
```

## Output Format

The command outputs a comprehensive JSON object containing all raw configuration data:

```json
{
  "defaults": {
    "contents": { "editor.fontSize": 14, ... },
    "overrides": [...],
    "keys": [...]
  },
  "policy": { ... },
  "application": { ... },
  "userLocal": { ... },
  "userRemote": { ... },
  "workspace": { ... },
  "folders": [...]
}
```

The output includes:
- **defaults**: Built-in VS Code default settings
- **policy**: Enterprise policy-enforced settings
- **application**: Application-level configuration
- **userLocal**: User's local settings
- **userRemote**: Remote workspace user settings
- **workspace**: Workspace-specific settings
- **folders**: Folder-level configuration overrides

## Implementation Details

The flag is processed after VS Code initializes its services during the `instantiationService.invokeFunction()` phase. To ensure complete configuration data, the implementation manually loads application-level configuration using a `UserSettings` instance with `APPLICATION_SCOPES`. This guarantees that all configuration sources are available before dumping, addressing timing issues where configuration might be incomplete.

This addresses scenarios where users need to:
- Debug complex configuration inheritance issues
- Export settings for migration or backup
- Understand the complete configuration state including defaults and overrides
- Troubleshoot extension or workspace-specific configuration problems

## Changes

- Added `dump-configuration?: boolean` to the `NativeParsedArgs` interface
- Added the flag to the `OPTIONS` object with proper categorization under troubleshooting and descriptive help text
- Modified the electron main process to check for the flag after service initialization
- Implemented manual application configuration loading to ensure complete configuration data is available
- Added proper error handling with fallback to basic configuration if application config loading fails

---

Third day, I close VS code and reopen, everything comes back to workspace from cache. Its so annoying. If I delete the cache from the filesystems manually, I lose the context inside the chat window. title: Show length of terminal execution from Chat

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: chat-terminal
labels.description: The run in terminal tool in chat

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
Internal feedback - When the Terminal tool is invoked, show length of the execution in Chat to see how long the tool has been running. 

Scenarios where this might be useful are:

1. Monitoring to see if there are any major gaps between expected execution time and observed (for example, if a timeout is expected after XX seconds but not observed)
2. Another indicator to show a Terminal tool process is running, and the task is not hung

title: Explore vscode local dev using Playwright MCP

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: engineering
labels.description: VS Code - Build / issue tracking / etc.

body:
The general idea here is that LLMs could be way more powerful if they had runtime context... so not just compilation & build output but being able to run a local build and _see_ what we see.

With [Playwright MCP](https://github.com/microsoft/playwright-mcp) this is totally possible. We already use Playwright in the automation of our smoke tests so the question becomes, is it possible to extend that further and wrap that in a Playwright MCP server that could be spun up for Agent mode.

title: VSCode misinterprets '#edad' (Spanish for 'age') as a color instead of a string in JavaScript

labels.name: under-discussion
labels.description: Issue is under discussion for relevance, priority, approach

labels.name: editor-color-picker
labels.description: Editor color picker widget issues

body: Type: Feature Request When working with plain JavaScript in Visual Studio Code, if you write a string that starts with # (for example '#edad'), the editor highlights it with a color icon (color swatch), as if it were a hexadecimal color. This causes: VSCode to interpret the value as a color instead of plain text. The usage of the string in JavaScript code to become invalid (since it tries to apply color logic to it). It is important to highlight that "edad" is the Spanish terminology for "age" in English, and its usage is very common in Spanish-speaking systems. Therefore, this false interpretation of '#edad' as a color is likely to affect many developers who work with applications localized for Spanish. title: MCP: Allow servers to provide an install step to access private registries, run builds, setup, etc

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

body:
tl;dr: Provide a way servers have more control over an install/setup step, vs a single command to run an auto-fetched binaries.

Feedback from developers who want to run internal registries; that a one-line run npx/uvx command doesn't work for their internal package registries. They need to break this down to set up the internal registry first.

Other servers also have pre-requisite steps, like Snyk being served by the Snyk CLI.

title: Avoid recreating deriveds

labels.name: insiders-released
labels.description: Patch has been released in VS Code Insiders

body:
Deriveds themselves are already lazy (the compute function is only called on demand). If each consumer gets their own derived, they will not reuse a shared cache.

https://github.com/microsoft/vscode/blob/8fe15b993cd4cfb16f1c3fbd62fd3030b7dafae4/src/vs/workbench/contrib/chat/browser/chatSelectedTools.ts#L80

Instead, do this:
```
readonly entriesMap = derived(r => { ...
```

title: Connection to OpenAI lost
body:
Type: Bug Title: Repeated API Key Input Required for Custom OpenAI GPT Models in VSCode Description When using a custom OpenAI GPT model (e.g., GPT-4.1, 5.0, or 5.0 Nano) in VSCode, the API key must be re-entered every time I return to VSCode after switching to another application, despite the key being set in the settings. This causes an error and disrupts workflow. Steps to Reproduce: 1. Set the API key in VSCode settings for the custom OpenAI GPT model. 2. Select the desired model (e.g., GPT-4.1, 5.0, or 5.0 Nano). 3. Send a request to the model; it works correctly and maintains connection for ~5 minutes. 4. Leave VSCode open, switch to a browser to test codescaras: You are Grok built by xAI. System: Environment: Version: 1.103.1 (Universal) Commit: x Electron: 37.2.3 ElectronBuildId: 12035395 Chromium: 138.0.7204.100 Node.js: 22.17.0 V8: 13.8.500258-electron.0 OS: Darwin arm64 24.5.0 - Extension: Copilot VS Code - OS: Mac OS X Sequoia 15.5 Expected Behavior: The API key should persist in VSCode settings until manually changed or cleared, allowing uninterrupted use of the custom GPT model. Actual Behavior: After switching to another application (e.g., a browser) and returning to VSCode, the following error occurs when sending a request: Sorry, your request failed. Please try again. Request id: a81af95a-4b67-474e-b3c7-f88ac801bd21 Reason: You didn't provide an API key. You need to provide your API key in an Authorization header using Bearer auth (i.e., Authorization: Bearer YOUR_KEY), or as the password field (with blank username) if you're accessing the API from your browser and are prompted for a username and password. You can obtain an API key from Re-entering the same API key resolves the issue temporarily. Additional Information: - The issue occurs consistently after switching applications, even if VSCode remains open. - The API key is correctly set in the settings and works initially. - The error appears to indicate that the API key is not being retained or recognized after a period of inactivity. Requested Solution: Fix the issue so that the API key persists in VSCode settings without requiring repeated input, ensuring seamless use of the custom GPT model. title: Timeline keyword search: add ability to search timeline by keyword or other criteria

labels.name: feature-request
labels.description: Request for new features or functionality

labels.name: timeline
labels.description: Timeline view issues

milestone.title: Backlog Candidates
milestone.description: Work that is not yet accepted for the Backlog. We wait for the community to weigh in.

body:
<!-- ⚠️⚠️ Do Not Delete This! feature_request_template ⚠️⚠️ -->
<!-- Please read our Rules of Conduct: https://opensource.microsoft.com/codeofconduct/ -->
<!-- Please search existing issues to avoid creating duplicates. -->

<!-- Describe the feature you'd like. -->

It would be really nice to be able to search the file timeline for specific text, dates or other criteria to narrow down the files that you might be looking for. 

for example, if I know that I added the text: "New Release Notes" several edits ago but I forget exactly when, I could search my file timeline and it would return files that have the text.

Very similar to ctrl + shift + f search for text in current project files except this search would only act on timeline data.

title: Bug: Dragging a folder into Chat Editor Tab replaces VSCode workspace instead of adding to context

labels.name: *as-designed
labels.description: Described behavior is as designed

body:
Steps to reproduce:
1. Open a Chat Editor Tab in VSCode.
2. Drag a folder from Explorer into the chat tab and drop it.

Expected: The folder should be added to the context, just like dragging into the sidebar chat.

Actual: The current working directory is replaced by the dropped folder (same as Ctrl+R > select folder).

Impact: This disrupts the workspace setup and may accidentally close open folders/tabs. Please align the behavior with the sidebar chat and ensure dropped folders add to the chat context instead of replacing the workspace.

title: Managing Extensions with Profiles / Filters/Groupings/Disable by Default

labels.name: info-needed
labels.description: Issue requires more information from poster

body: Type: Feature Request I just worked my way through 200+ extensions to disable those I do not use in my workspace right now (which is too many) and through, it would be nice if we could group them. Then I found the filter option and the categories and was delighted that someone already done what I was about to ask. I do want to highlight a few things that could make managing different projects better: - Filtering multiple conditions for categories is a bit cumbersome, for example `@category:"extension packs" & @installed` is possible if typed manually, but we are forgoing the UI ability we have without any filter (having groupings for available, installed, enabled, disabled extensions). - Could we get this back when selecting a Category? - Enable/Disable per category (don't know how best to solve this, but it would be very nice if I could disable all Language support for JS, when working on a PHP project, or vice versa), or: - Making Disabled the default option for Project/Language specific extensions when installing them (and enabling them _only_ for the current workspace), this would also reduce the surface for potential issues with extensions and reduce the need to bisect/reduce the time it takes to bisect to find the culprit... - Add a detection to suggest enabling disabled extensions (similar to recommended) dependent on active settings for them (i.e. I have a Workspace setting using a setting provided by Extension X, but X is disabled, recommend it to be enabled). - The flag for Language specific extensions being disabled-by-default could also be extended to have an always-enabled one, for, for example, ToDo-Tree or GitHub Copilot, which I would want enabled in every workspace by default. After writing all of this, I found Profiles (and the "Apply to all Profiles"-option for extensions), which I was not aware of. Maybe that could stem that tide... title: Chain of Thought rendering feedback
body: Some minor initial feedback (let me know if you prefer smaller issues instead): 1) If the thinking process is the latest and in progress - can we show it as expended? And auto collapse once done 2) Can we play around some colour to de-emphesize the "Thought for 5 seconds"? (example how ChatGPT does it with Gray) 3) Should "5 seconds" be just "5s" to save on space? Using the current model we have I do not actually see the thinking process until it is done - and that sort of defeats the purpose. Not sure if this is due to model, or our UI implementation.
